revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{like resume|date=September 2014}}{{BLP sources|date=July 2013}} {{Orphan|date=July 2013}} }}
{{infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = José Carlos Caetano Xavier | image = Jose Xavier 1.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|04|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Coimbra]], [[Portugal]] | occupation = Portuguese scientist and Polar explorer | language = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | nationality = [[Portugal|Portuguese]] | website = [http://cientistapolarjxavier.blogspot.com/ Official Blog] }}
'''José Carlos Caetano Xavier''' is a Portuguese scientist ([[Marine biology|Marine biologist]]) and [[Antarctica|Polar]] explorer.
==Early life and education== Xavier graduated from [[University of Algarve]] with a master's degree in Marine Biology in 1997 and earned a Ph.D. from the [[University of Cambridge]] (Queen´s college) in 1999. He has been carrying out [[Antarctic]] research since 1997, on 7 research expeditions (comprising more than 3 years); most recently in 2012.
==Career== Xavier is a principal investigator of the Institute of Marine Research of the [[University of Coimbra]] <ref>[http://www1.ci.uc.pt/imar/unit/people/cvs/cv/j_xavier.php Institute of Marine Research of the University of Coimbra]</ref>(Portugal) and at the [[British Antarctic Survey]] (Cambridge, UK) collaborating with researchers from more than 15 countries.
He was one of the leading scientists for the implementation of the national research program PROPOLAR and of the educational program LATITUDE60!, during the [[International Polar Year]].
Xavier co-founded the [[Association of Polar Early Career Scientists]] and is also a member of the Education and Outreach sub-committee of the International Polar Year. He is involved in more than 40 educational activities and events, nationally and internationally, giving talks in schools, producing exhibitions and directing educational films, among other activities.
He was involved in the institutional efforts for Portugal to join the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (2006), European Polar Board (2007) and signing the [[Antarctic Treaty]] (2010). He co-led Portugal's polar science, education and outreach activities during the [[International Polar Year]].
===Investigation interests=== In his research areas are Marine Biology, Behavioral Ecology, Oceanography, Modeling, Foraging and Feeding Ecology. Xavier studies the foraging behavior and feeding ecology of top predators (namely [[penguin]]<nowiki/>s, [[albatross]]<nowiki/>es and [[Seal (mammal)|seals]]) in relation to [[climate change]]. As a marine biologist, his main research areas are focused on understanding [[food web]] dynamics in [[marine ecosystems]]. Xavier studies penguins, albatrosses, seals and other mammals, sharks, conger eels and other fish, turtles, paying special attention to Cephalopods in the diet of top predators. [[File:Jose_Xavier_2.jpg|thumb|José Xavier in the Institute of Marine Research of the University of Coimbra]] * Behavioral ecology of top predators in relation to climate change in the Antarctic Ocean * Food choices of top predators: squid, fish or krill * Quantification of the impact of predators in ocean resources: implications on conservation and fisheries management
[[File:Jose Xavier in Antarctic.jpg|thumb|José Xavier in Antarctic]]
==Awards== In 2011, Xavier was the youngest recipient of the Martha T. Muse Prize for his work on science and politics in the Antarctic<ref>[http://www.museprize.org/news.html Martha T Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica]</ref>
==Books== * {{cite book|first1=José C. |last1=Xavier|title=Experiência Antárctica Relatos de um Cientista Polar Português|url=http://www.gradiva.pt/?q=C/BOOKSSHOW/7629|date=2014|publisher=gradiva|isbn=978-989-616-572-7}} * {{cite book|first1=José C. |last1=Xavier|first2=Gonçalo T. |last2=Vieira|first3=Adelino |last3=Canário|title=Portuguese Science Strategy for the International Polar Year|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=bs7vPgAACAAJ}}|date=2006|publisher=Portuguese Committee for the International Polar Year 2007-08}} * {{cite book|first1=JC |last1=Xavier |first2=Y |last2=Cherel|title=Cephalopod beak guide for the Southern Ocean|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=TTUTmRfywzcC}}|publisher=Jose Xavier|id=GGKEY:B12NB0YD37G |year=2009}}
==Scientific societies== [[File:Jose Xavier workshop Coimbra.jpg|thumb|José Xavier during Polar Educators Workshop in Coimbra, Portugal]] * Scientific committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR) research program SCAR Ant-ERA (Antarctic Thresholds – Ecosystems resilience and adaptation) (Scientific Steering Committee member; 2012- now) * Foundation for Science and Technology (Scientific consultant; 2011- now) * Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR) Development Council (Executive committee, Western Europe Representative and Vice-Chair for Early Career Scientists) (2011- now) * Co-secretary and newsletter editor of the research program Evolution and Biodiversity in the Antarctic (EBA), of the Scientific Committee of Antarctic Research (SCAR) (2010- now) * Finance Committee of the Scientific Committee of the Antarctic Research (2010-now) * Scientific standing group of Life Sciences of the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR) (APECS international nominated representative) (2010) * Scientific Committee of the research program Integrating Climate and Ecosystem Dynamics for the Southern Ocean (ICED), program integrated in Globec and IMBER.mber of the Scientific Standing Group of Life Sciences of the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR; Portugal representative)) * Financial Committee for the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research * Research Program Evolution and Biodiversity for the Antarctic (EBA) of the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR) * Capacity Building, Education and Training of SCAR (Portugal representative) * Expert group for Birds and Marine Mammals of SCAR * Portuguese Committee for the International Polar Year (IPY) * Executive Committee Member of the Polar Early Career Scientists (APECS; 2007-2009) [[File:Jose Xavier 4.jpg|thumb|José Xavier on Livingston Island, South Shetlands, Antarctica]] * Cephalopod International Advisory Council (CIAC) * Geographic Society of Lisbon (SGL) * Fellow of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (CPS), UK * Fellow of the Cambridge European Trust (CET), UK * Life-member of the Cambridge University Biological Society (CUBS), UK * Collaborator of Cephalopod Web Database (Cephbase) see https://web.archive.org/web/20060118140436/http://www.cephbase.utmb.edu/ * Life-member Queens ´College, University of Cambridge (MQC), UK * Conservation of Nature Institute (Instituto de conservação da natureza - ICN), Portugal
[[File:Hannah Point.jpg|thumb|José Xavier in Hanna Point, Antarctica]]
==Referee and editor== * 2011 – Nominated to join the SCAR Development Council * 2011 – Coordinator for the signature of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Foundation to the Science and Technology (Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia) and the * * British Antarctic Survey * 2010-2011 – Secretary and newsletter editor of the research program Evolution and Biodiversity in the Antarctic (EBA), of the Scientific Committee of Antarctic Research (SCAR) * 2011 – Member of the scientific commission of the program PROPOLAR <ref>[http://www.propolar.org/equipa-no-terreno-1ordf-campanha.html Programa Polar Português (PROPOLAR) - Campanha Antártica 2011-12] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224175501/http://www.propolar.org/equipa-no-terreno-1ordf-campanha.html |date=2013-02-24 }}</ref> * 2011 – Reviewer and scientific coordinating commission member of the mobility program “New generation of Early Career Scientists” from the bank CGD * 2010-2011 – Reviewer of SCAR Fellowships for Life Sciences (awarding 15 000 euros in fellowships) * 2010 – Stipend Committee of the OSLO IPY Conference for the evaluation of scholarships for early career scientists * 2010 – Life Science Selection Committee for the Travel Grants for South American researchers to attend the Oslo IPY (invited by Tinker Foundation and Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR)). * 2007-2010 – Invited Scientist for International Polar Year Days * Editorial Board Member of the Open Fish Science Journals (since May 2007) * Journal Referee – Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, Polar Biology, Marine Ecology Progress Series, Marine Biology, Reviews for Fish Biology and Fisheries, Ecography, Ibis (International journal of avian science of the British Ornithologists’ Union), Emu ( Austral Ornithology is the premier journal for ornithological research and reviews in the Southern Hemisphere), Aquatic Living Resources, Journal of Avian Biology, ACTA ZOOLOGICA SINICA, Fisheries Research * Referee for National funding organizations – US NSF (American National Science Foundation) and NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada)
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.museprize.org/news.html 2011 Martha T Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica, Tinker Foundation] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120325202618/http://www.sciencepoles.org/articles/article_detail/jose_xavier_winner_of_the_2011_martha_t._muse_prize/ 2011 Martha T. Muse Prize, International Polar Foundation, October 18, 2011] * [http://cientistapolarjxavier.blogspot.com/ Official Blog] * [http://whyscience.co.uk/contributors/jose-xavier/jose-xavier-my-way-of-helping-the-penguins.html My way of helping the penguins, Why is science important?, December 17, 2008] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AkJwjjzcTGk YouTube (in Portuguese), Mar 11, 2008] * [http://upmagazine-tap.com/en/pt_artigos/jose-xavier-2/ Professional traveller, UP Magazine (TAP Airlines), Sep 01, 2010]

revision.comment: /* Rice dishes */Typo fixing, replaced: yougurt → yogurt, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: It’s → It's
revision.text:
This is a '''list of rice dishes''' from all over the world, arranged alphabetically. [[Rice]] is the [[seed]] of the [[monocot]] plants ''[[Oryza sativa]]'' (Asian rice) or ''[[Oryza glaberrima]]'' (African rice). As a [[cereal|cereal grain]], it is the most widely consumed [[staple food]] for a large part of the world's human population, especially in Asia and the [[West Indies]]. It is the grain with the second-highest worldwide production, after [[maize]] (corn), according to data for 2010.<ref name="prodstat">{{cite web | url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/567/DesktopDefault.aspx | title=ProdSTAT | work=FAOSTAT | accessdate=December 26, 2006}}</ref>
==Rice dishes== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" ! Name ! class="unsortable"| Image ! Origin ! Description |- | [[Akki rotti]] [ಅಕ್ಕಿ ರೊಟ್ಟಿ] | [[File:Akki rotti.JPG|122px]] | [[India]] | "Rice bread", a rice-based breakfast item unique to the state of [[Karnataka]], [[India]] |- | [[Albaloo polo]] آلبالو پلو | [[File:Persian-sour-cherry-saffron-rice-polow.jpg |122px]] | [[Iran]] | Sour (morello) cherries in pilaf rice, usually made with spices like [[saffron]] and [[advieh]]. |- | [[American fried rice]] (Thai) | [[File:American fried rice.jpg|122px]] | [[Thailand]] | This is a dish from [[Thai cuisine]] where the rice is fried with tomato ketchup and raisins |- | [[Arancini]] | [[File:Arancini_002.jpg|122px]] | [[Italy]] ([[Sicily]]) | Breaded and deep fried stuffed rice balls |- | [[Arroz caldo]] | | [[Philippines]] | Thin rice [[porridge]] cooked with chicken, [[ginger]], onions and garnished with spring onions, toasted garlic and [[calamansi]] |- | [[Arroz chaufa]] | [[File:Arroz chaufa simple.JPG|122px]] | [[Peru]] | "Chow fun rice" Chinese fried rice with a Peruvian twist |- | Arroz borracho | | [[Puerto Rico]] | Rice cooked with [[Bixa orellana|sazón]], sofrito, chickpeas, ground meat, and beer. |- | [[Arroz con gandules]] | [[File:Arroz con gandules.jpg|122px]] | [[Puerto Rico]] | A part of the Puerto Rican gastronomy consisting of a combination of rice, [[pigeon pea]]s, olives, capers, and pork, cooked in the same pot with Puerto Rican-style [[sofrito]], spices and annatto oil.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rivera|first=Oswald|title=Puerto Rican Cuisine in America: Nuyorican and Bodega Recipes|publisher=9781568582443|year=2002|pages=186|isbn=978-1-56858-244-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZ6uqpUG8ksC&pg=PA186}}</ref> |- | [[Arroz con huevo frito]] | [[File:HK Sheung Wan Cafe de Coral pan-fried egg Luncheon meat rice Aug-2012.JPG|122px]] | [[Central America]] and [[South America]] | Rice with fried egg |- | [[Arroz con pollo]] | [[File:Arroz-con-Pollo.jpg|122px]] | [[Spain]] | "Rice with chicken", the dish, which originated in Spain as a form of [[pilaf]], is a staple throughout [[Latin America]].<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Elisabeth Lambert Ortiz]]|title=Cocina latinoamericana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5cCC4MAVEkcC&pg=PA251|accessdate=9 August 2011 |date=9 September 1998 |publisher=EDAF|isbn=978-84-414-0421-2|page=251}}</ref><ref name=mclean>{{cite book|author=Alice L. McLean|title=Cooking in America, 1840–1945 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FqWbumBZ0p0C&pg=PA139|accessdate=8 August 2011|date=30 August 2006 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-313-33574-7|page=139}}</ref><ref name="WeirHess1998">{{cite book|author1=Robert M. Weir|author2=Karen Hess|title=The Carolina Rice Kitchen: The African Connection |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_yIJBQDY0H0C&pg=PA39|accessdate=8 August 2011|date=March 1998|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press |isbn=978-1-57003-208-0 |page=39}}</ref><ref name="JonesBaraka2011">{{cite book|author1=Kellie Jones |author2=Amiri Baraka |author3=Lisa Jones |author4=Hettie Jones |author5=Guthrie P. Ramsey |title=EyeMinded: Living and Writing Contemporary Art |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IPaFCHEz8-cC&pg=PA285 |accessdate=8 August 2011|date=6 May 2011|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=978-0-8223-4873-3|page=285}}</ref><ref name="Figueredo2002">{{cite book|author=D. H. Figueredo|title=The complete idiot's guide to Latino history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=caC_38oDw6sC&pg=PT250 |accessdate=8 August 2011|date=16 July 2002|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-02-864360-1|page=250}}</ref> It is a traditional dish of [[Latin America]] and [[the Caribbean]], especially in [[Puerto Rico]], [[Colombia]], [[Venezuela]], [[Ecuador]], [[Panama]], [[Peru]], [[Cuba]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Honduras]], the [[Dominican Republic]] where it is called locrio de pollo, and [[Saint Martin]] where it is called lokri or locreo. |- | [[Arroz de lisa]] (mullet rice) | [[File:Arroz de lisa 2 - Barranquilla.jpg|122px]] | [[Colombia]], Caribbean region | Traditionally served in [[bijao]] leaf with cooked [[cassava]], a triangle of [[costeño cheese]] and a sauce of [[suero atollabuey]] |- | [[Arroz negro]] | [[File:Arrosnegre.png|122px]] | [[Spain]] | "Black rice", dish blackened with [[cuttlefish]] ink |- | [[Baghali polo]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Iran]] | This is rice with [[lima bean]]s and [[dill]]. |- | [[Bánh chưng]] | [[File:Bánh chưng.jpg|122px]] | [[Vietnam]] | This is a cake-dish usually eaten on Tet, Vietnamese new year eve, which is pork in the center, mashed pea and rice wrapped in leaves. |- | [[Ba-wan]] | [[File:Bawan umiao.jpg|122px]] | [[Taiwan]] | This is a savory snack food made from rice paste, meat, and usually [[shiitake]] mushrooms and [[bamboo shoot]]s. It is often found at Taiwan night markets. Also called "rou-wan-zhi." |- | [[Bi pong moun]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Cambodia]] | A rice and egg dish. Several variations exist. |- | [[Bibimbap]] | [[File:Korean cuisine-Bibimbap-08.jpg|122px]] | [[Korea]] | Mixed vegetables on rice |- | [[Bibingka]] | [[File:Large bibinka.jpg|122px]] | [[Philippines]] | A rice cake usually eaten during [[Christmas]]. May be topped with cottage cheese, salted egg or freshly grated shredded young [[coconut]] meat. |- | [[Biko (food)|Biko]] | [[File:Biko.jpg|122px]] | [[Philippines]] | A sweet dish made of sticky rice cooked in [[coconut milk]] and sugar and topped with thick caramelized coconut syrup and ''latik'' |- |[[Biryani]] |[[File:Dum biryani.JPG|122px]] |[[Indian subcontinent]] | Preparation of spicy fried rice with meat, fish, chicken, and vegetables. |- |[[Bisi bele bath]] |[[File:Bisi Bele Bath.jpg|122px]] |[[India]] | A rice-based dish with its origins in the state of [[Karnataka]], [[India]]. ''Bisi-bele-bhaath'' translates to ''hot lentil rice'' in the [[Kannada]] language. The traditional preparation of this dish is quite elaborate and involves the use of spicy [[spice mix|masala]], [[toor dal]] (a type of lentil) and [[vegetables]]. Spices like [[nutmeg]] and [[asafoetida]], [[curry leaves]] and [[tamarind]] pulp used in its preparation contribute to the unique flavor and taste of this dish. |- |[[Boiled Rice|Bhaat]] |[[File:Meshi.jpg|122px]] |[[Indian subcontinent]] | Rice that has been cooked either by steaming or boiling. |- |[[Bokkeumbap]] |[[File:Korea-Busan-Haeundae Market-Bokkeumbap-Fried rice-01.jpg|122px]] |[[Korea]] | Fried rice, usually with some other ingredient, like [[kimchi bokkeumbap]] ([[Kimchi]] fried rice) |- |[[Boribap]] |[[File:Boribap.JPG|122px]] |[[Korea]] | Rice boiled with [[barley]] |- |[[Boudin]] |[[File:Smoked_Boudin_Blanc.jpg|122px]] |[[United States]] | Cajun rice dressing stuffed into a sausage casing. |- |[[Cabidela]] |[[File:PortoExterior PatoDeCabidela.JPG|122px]] |[[Portugal]] | Rice with chicken or rabbit meat. |- |[[Chalbap]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> |[[Korea]] | Cooked sweet rice mixed with red beans, [[jujube]]s and [[chestnut]]s |- |[[Rice congee#Vietnam|Chao]] |[[File:Cháo trắng hột vịt muối.JPG|122px]] |[[Vietnam]] | |- |[[Chazuke]] | |[[Japan]] |[[Dashi]], green tea, or hot water poured over cooked rice. Common toppings include Japanese pickles ([[tsukemono]]), [[nori]], and fish roe such as [[Tarako (food)|tarako]] or [[mentaiko]]. |- |[[Chimichanga]] |[[File:Chimichanga in Bremen 7095.JPG|122px]] | Mexico and parts of southern [[United States]] | This is a deep-fried burrito most commonly made with rice, cheese, machaca, carne adobada, or shredded chicken, and folding it into a rectangular package, and deep-frying. |- |[[Carri]] |[[File:Carri-poulet.jpg|122px]] |[[Mauritius]], [[Réunion]] | Rice, with chicken or beef, tomatoes, chili and curry |- |[[Chitranna]] |[[File:Chitranna (Lemon Rice) prepared by an indian woman.jpg|122px]] |[[India]] | This is a rice preparation made by sauting [[groundnut]], [[sesame seed]]s, red chili and [[turmeric]] in oil and adding it to cooked rice and mixing. |- |[[Ci fan tuan]] |[[File:CiFanTuan.png|122px]] |[[Shanghai]] ([[China]]), and [[Taiwan]] | Prepared by tightly wrapping a piece of ''[[youtiao]]'' (fried dough) with [[glutinous rice]]. |- |[[Claypot chicken rice]] |[[File:Claypot Chicken Rice, Singapore.JPG|122px]] |[[China]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]] | This is a rice dish served with sliced chicken, salted fish, Chinese sausage and vegetables. The rice is cooked in the claypot first and the cooked ingredients are added in later. Some places serve it with dark soya sauce. Traditionally, the cooking is done over a charcoal stove, giving the dish a distinctive flavour. |- |[[Cơm tấm]] |[[File:Com-Tam-2008.jpg|122px]] |[[Vietnam]] | A dish in [[Vietnamese cuisine]] made from [[rice]] with fractured rice grains. ''Tấm'' refers to the [[broken rice|broken rice grains]], while ''cơm'' refers to cooked rice.<ref name="saigon">[[Thanh Nien]] [http://www.thanhniennews.com/2010/pages/20120105-hot-spots.aspx Hot Spots] 5 Jan 2012 "With your craftsmanship in hand, return to Saigon for a master class in clay-pot cooking, crafting cơm tấm (broken rice), caramelized pork belly,"</ref><ref>Meera Freeman ''The Flavours of Vietnam'' 2004 - Page 42 "Cơm tấm - broken rice. 3 cups broken rice water vegetable oil (optional) Rinse the rice in plenty of cold running water until the water is clear and the rice is free of impurities. Put the washed rice in a large saucepan ..."</ref> |- |[[Congee]] |[[File:Chinese rice congee.jpg|122px]] |[[East Asia|East]], [[South Asia|South]], and [[Southeast Asia]] | A type of porridge. Sometimes called "rice congee" but often simply shortened to "congee." There is a large variety of congee in Hong Kong and it is eaten very frequently as a [[staple food]]. The base is made by boiling rice then letting it simmer for a long time. Different ingredients are added depending on the region. The length of the simmering also varies by region. Cantonese congee is generally cooked longer for a smoother texture. |- |[[Coriander rice]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> |[[India]] | Easily made by using boiled rice, [[coriander]] paste, oil, [[chana dal]], [[cumin]] seeds, [[jeere]], lemon juice and salt. |- |[[Curd rice]] |[[File:Curd rice.jpg|122px]] |[[India]] | Simple preparations are a mixture of boiled rice and yogurt. More complex variations also exist. |- |[[Japanese curry|Curry rice]] |[[File:Curry rice by Hyougushi in Kyoto.jpg|122px]] |[[Japan]], and also popular in other parts of [[East Asia|East]] and [[Southeast Asia]] | Although [[curry]] is often eaten with rice in many countries it is seen as a main dish. The Japanese ''karē raisu'' (lit. "curry rice") though, is a standard combination of rice with a British influenced Japanese curry, of which there exist several types. |- |[[Dal bhat]] |[[File:Dalbath.jpg|122px]] |[[Indian subcontinent]] | Rice and lentil soup |- | [[Biryani#Danbauk|Dan Bauk]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Myanmar]] | Burmese style Biryani |- | [[Dirty Rice]] | [[File:Pork chop and dirty rice.jpg|122px]] | [[Cajun cuisine]], [[Creole cuisine]] | Pictured is dirty rice topped with a [[pork chop]] |- | [[Dolma]] | [[File:Azerbaijan dolma ubergine pepper.jpg|122px]] | [[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Turkey]], [[Middle East]] | [[Eggplant]], Zucchini, peppers, onion or tomatoes stuffed with rice. |- | [[Dosa]] | [[File:Dosai Chutney Hotel Saravana Bhavan.jpg|122px]] | [[India]] | Rice and [[lentil]] pancakes with origins in [[Udipi]], [[Karnataka]]. Popular breakfast dish in South India. |- | [[Étouffée]] | [[File:053107-crayfishetouffee.jpg|122px]] | [[Cajun]], [[Creole cuisine]] | Found in both [[Cajun cuisine|Cajun]] and [[Louisiana Creole cuisine|Creole]] cuisine, Étouffée is typically prepared with [[shellfish]] over rice. The dish employs a technique known as [[Smothering (food)|smothering]], a popular method of cooking in the [[Cajun]] areas of southwest [[Louisiana]]. |- | [[Fried rice]] | [[File:Fried rice in Singapore.jpg|122px]] | [[China]] | Pictured is Chinese-style fried rice from Singapore |- | [[Fried rice]] (Philippines) | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Philippines]] | Day old rice fried in oil with a lot of garlic, usually eaten for breakfast with [[dried fish]], egg and tomatoes. |- | [[Gaifan]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[China]], [[Taiwan]] | Cooked rice covered with another dish. |- | [[Gallo pinto]] | [[File:Costa Rican Gallo Pinto.jpg|122px]] | [[Central America]]n countries such as [[Costa Rica]] and [[Nicaragua]] | A [[Latin American cuisine|Central American]] version of rice and beans |- | [[Gimbap]] | [[File:Korean.food-Kimbap-03.jpg|122px]] | [[Korea]] | Rice wrapped in [[Edible seaweed|seaweed]] |- | [[Glutinous rice]] cakes | [[File:Korean.food-teok-01.jpg|122px]] | | E.g. [[Mochi (food)|mochi]] (Japan), [[Ddeok]] (Korea), [[Tangyuan (food)|tangyuan]], [[niangao]], [[zongzi]] (China), and many varieties of [[Thai cuisine|Thai]] and [[Laotian cuisine|Laotian]] cakes. |- | [[Goto (food)|Goto]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Philippines]] | Thin rice [[porridge]] cooked with strips of ox-tripe, ginger, onion, garlic, and [[Garnish (food)|garnished]] with [[spring onion]]s and [[calamansi]]. |- | [[Gumbo]] | [[File:Mmm... gumbo (7858028252) (2).jpg|122px]] | [[Cajun]], [[Louisiana Creole cuisine|Creole]] | Considered a soup but served over rice. |- | [[Hainanese chicken rice]] | [[File:Hainanese Chicken Rice.jpg|122px]] | [[China]] | |- | [[Hainanese curry rice]] | | [[Singapore]] | A [[Singaporean]] rice dish consisting of steamed white rice smothered in a mess of curries and gravy. |- | [[Havij Polo]] | [[File:Havij polo.jpg|122px]] | [[Iran]] | Carrot Rice with minced meat balls usually cooked in [[Tehran]] and other cities of Iran |- | [[Hoppin' John]] | [[File:Hoppin-john-bowl.JPG|122px]] | Southern [[United States]] | Rice, [[black eyed beans]] and [[pork]] |- | [[Horchata]] | [[File:Horchata jar.jpg|122px]] | [[Mexico]] | Sugared [[rice milk]]. |- | [[Htamin Baung]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Myanmar]] | [[Steamed rice]] cooked with chicken and vegetables, of Chinese origin |- | [[Idli]] | [[File:Idli Sambar.JPG|122px]] | [[India]] | Steamed rice cakes, made with [[lentils]] or other pulses. Pictured is idli along with ramekins of [[sambar (dish)|sambar]] and a ramekin of [[chutney]] in the center of the dish. |- | [[Imbul Kiribath]] | | [[Sri Lanka]] | Tightly wrapped [[Kiribath]] with treacle soaked scraped coconut (Pani-pol) in it. |- | [[Indonesian rice table]] | [[File:Rijsttafel Den Haag Javastraat.jpg|122px]] | [[Indonesia]] | Rice accompanied by side dishes served in small portions. Usually known as Rijsttafel |- | [[Iskilip Dolmasi]] | [[File:Iskilip dolmasi - Corum.jpg|122px]] | [[Turkey]] | Very specific rice food. It takes almost a day to prepare and cook. Cooked for several hundred years only in Iskilip. Extremely traditional and rare. |-
| [[Jambalaya]] | [[File:Cooking Jambalaya near done.JPG|122px]] | [[Cajun]], [[Louisiana Creole cuisine|Creole]] | Meat-seafood-vegetable stock to which rice is added. |- | [[Jíbaro (dish)|Jíbaro]] | | [[Puerto Rico]] | Yellow-rice cooked with annatto oil, sofrito, and spices with a fried egg on top. |- | [[Jiuniang]] | [[File:Kueh hrua lau cau.jpg|122px]] | [[China]] | This is a sweet dish made from [[Fermentation in food processing|fermenting]] sticky rice with yeast. This can be eaten alone steamed, or is added to other foods. |- | [[Jollof rice]] | [[File:Jollof rice.jpg|122px]] | [[West Africa]] | <!--The Jollof live in Senegal/Gambia.--> tomato and pepper based [[stew]] to which rice is added and boiled in, and usually served with chicken, salad and fried [[Plantain (cooking)|plantain]]. |- |Ofada rice | |[[Nigeria]] |Ofada rice is a local Nigerian Delicacy eaten in Palm leaves.It is made from locally produced grown rice It is usually garnished with cow meat parts and fried ground pepper |- | [[Juk (food)|Juk]] | [[File:Korean cuisine-Juk-01.jpg|122px]] | [[Korea]] | Generic term for [[porridge]] made from rice. There are many different varieties. |- | [[Kabsa]] | [[File:Kabsa.jpg|122px]] | [[KSA]], [[Jordan]] | Rice (usually long-grain, mostly [[basmati]]) cooked with meat, spices and vegetables. |- |[[Kande Pohe]] | <!--[[File:Poha,_a_snack_made_of_flattened_rice.jpg|122px]] --> |[[India]] | A simple flattened rice dish from [[Maharashtra]] usually eaten as breakfast. |- | [[Kateh]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Iran]] | A simple sticky-rice dish from [[Mazandaran]] and [[Gilan]]. |- | [[Katsudon]] | [[File:Katsudon 01.jpg|122px]] | [[Japan]] | A bowl of rice topped with a deep-fried pork cutlet, egg, and condiments. |- | [[Kedgeree]] | [[File:Kedgeree.jpg|122px]] | [[India]] | Flaked fish (usually smoked [[haddock]]), boiled rice, eggs and butter. |- | [[Ketupat]] | [[File:Ketupat.jpg|122px]] | [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]] | (Also called [[Lontong]]) - Rice wrapped in coconut leaves weaved pouch, boiled and serve with other food such as [[Satay]], vegetables, fried chicken, curry, etc. |- | [[Khao kan chin]] | [[File:2013 Khao kan chin.jpg|122px]] | [[Thai cuisine|Thailand]] | A northern Thai dish of rice that is mixed with pork blood and steamed inside a banana leaf. It is served with cucumber, onions and fried, dried chillies. |- | Khao kha mu | [[File:Khao kha mu 02.JPG|122px]] | [[Thai cuisine|Thailand]] | Originally a [[Thai Chinese]] dish, it is rice served with sliced pork leg that has been stewed in soy sauce and spices |- | [[Khao khluk kapi]] | [[File:Khao.kluke.kapi-01.jpg|122px]] | [[Thai cuisine|Thailand]] | Rice is fried with [[shrimp paste]] and served with sweet pork, sour mango, fried shrimp, chillies and shallots. |- | Khao lam | [[File:Khao lam87.jpg|122px]] | [[Thai cuisine|Thailand]] | [[Glutinous rice]] is boiled or steamed with sugar, and sometimes other ingredients, in a section of bamboo. Most often eaten as a snack or dessert. Traditionally, it is prepared using a small [[charcoal]] [[Grill (cooking)|grill]] but in modern times a gas grill can be used. During the time of the Autumn Moon it is traditional to eat fresh yakimochi while sipping [[sake]] and enjoying the view of the full [[moon]]. |- | [[Yay Monte]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Myanmar]] | Thin savory rice pancake with boiled garden peas, spring onions and salted sesame garnish |- | [[Yeung Chow fried rice]] | [[File:Chinese fried rice by stu spivack in Cleveland, OH.jpg|122px]] |[[China]] | A popular [[Chinese cuisine|Chinese]]-style [[wok]] [[fried rice]] dish in many [[Chinese cuisine|Chinese]] restaurants in [[China]], [[the Americas]], [[Australia]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Vietnam]], and the [[Philippines]]. The ingredients vary, but there are staple items such as cooked rice (preferably day old because freshly cooked rice is too sticky, barbecued pork, Cooked [[shrimp]], [[scallion]]s (spring onions or green onions), chopped, including green ends and [[egg yolk]]s. |- | [[Yin yang fried rice]] | [[File:Yuanyangchaofan.jpg|122px]] | [[Hong Kong]] | Dish served with chicken in tomato sauce on one side, and shrimp and peas in an egg white sauce on the other, shaped into a yin yang symbol, with rice as base. |- | [[Zarda (food)|Zarda]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Indian subcontinent]] | Sweet dish of rice cooked in [[clarified butter]]/ banaspati oil<!--What is banaspati oil?--> with a variety of dried fruits such as orange in color |- | [[Zeera rice]]/ Jeera rice | [[File:Jeera-rice.JPG|122px]] | [[India]] | Steamed rice, Zeera ([[cumin]]), Zeera powder, ginger-garlic paste, salt, oil, chana dal and red chillies. |- | [[Zereshk polo]] | <!--[[File:EXAMPLE|122px]] --> | [[Qazvin Province]], [[Iran]] | This is caramelized [[barberries]] sprinkled on plain buttery basmati rice and served usually with chicken. |- | [[Zongzi]] | [[File:RiceDumpling.JPG|122px]] | [[China]] | Glutinous rice, stuffed with various ingredients and wrapped in bamboo leaves |- | [[Uppudu pindi]] | [[File:Broken_rice_upma_%26_coconut_chutney.jpg| 122px]] | [[India]] | A rice dish made from rice flour, made like [[upma]], eaten in [[Telangana]]. |- | [[Zosui]] | [[File:Kinokozousui (Gusto Restaurant).jpg|122px]] | [[Japan]] | A rice [[soup]] made from pre-cooked rice and water. Leftover soup from [[Nabemono|nabe]] is often re-used for zosui. |}

This is a '''list of notable sandwiches'''. A [[sandwich]] is a dish consisting of two or more slices of [[bread]] with one or more fillings between them,Abelson, Jenn. [http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2006/11/10/arguments_spread_thick/ "Arguments spread thick"]. ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', 10 November 2006. Retrieved 27 May 2009.{{cite web|title=sandwich|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sandwich|work=Merriam-Webster|publisher=Merriam-Webster, Incorporated|accessdate=29 March 2012}}{{cite book|title=Foundations of Restaurant Management & Culinary Arts Level Two|year=2011|publisher=Pearson|isbn=978-0-13-138022-6|page=53}} or one slice in the case of an [[open sandwich]]. Sandwiches are a common type of lunch food often eaten as part of a [[packed lunch]]. There are many types of sandwiches, made from a diverse variety of ingredients. The sandwich is the [[namesake]] of [[John Montagu, 4th Earl of Sandwich]], a British statesman. Major types of sandwich include: * Two slices of [[bread]] with other ingredients between * Two halves of a baguette with other ingredients between * [[Pocket sandwich]] * [[Open-faced sandwich]] [[Sandwich cookie]]s and [[ice cream sandwich]]es are generally not considered sandwiches in the sense of a bread-containing food item, but are named by analogy. ==Sandwiches== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- !Name !class="unsortable"| Image !Origin !Description |- | [[Bacon sandwich|Bacon]] | [[File:Baconbutty.jpg|120px]] | [[British cuisine|United Kingdom]] | Often eaten with [[ketchup]] or [[brown sauce]] |- | [[Bacon, egg and cheese sandwich|Bacon, egg and cheese]] | [[File:Egg and cheese breakfast sandwich.jpg|120px]] | [[American cuisine|United States]] | [[Breakfast sandwich]], usually with fried or scrambled egg |- | [[Bagel toast]] | [[File:Bagel Toast.jpg|120px|Bagel toast]] | Israel | Pressed, toasted bagel filled with vegetables and cheese and grilled on a sandwich toaster or [[panini press]] |- | [[Baked bean sandwich|Baked bean]] | [[File:Baked bean sandwich.jpg|120px]] | United States | Canned [[baked beans]] on white or brown bread, sometimes with butter. |- | ''[[Bánh mì]]''Nicholls, Walter (February 6, 2008). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/05/AR2008020500888.html The Banh Mi of My Dreams]. ''Washington Post''. | [[File:Bánh mì thịt nướng.png|120px]] | [[Vietnamese cuisine|Vietnam]] | Filling is typically meat, but can contain a wide range of foods, including [[sardines]], tofu, [[pâté]], or eggs. Served on an airy [[baguette]] with pickled [[carrots]], [[cilantro]] and peppers. |- | [[Barbecue sandwich|Barbecue]]{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tk2dMJL-HWsC&pg=PA315&dq=barbecue+sandwich&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QP5aUfX6AsPOiwKzioAQ&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=barbecue+sandwich&f=false|title=Modern Garde Manger: A Global Perspective|first1=Robert B.|last1=Garlough|first2=Angus|last2=Campbell|date=16 November 2012|publisher=Cengage Learning|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E8vhbo4so_0C&pg=PA157&dq=barbecue+sandwich&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QP5aUfX6AsPOiwKzioAQ&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=barbecue+sandwich&f=false|title=Serious Eats: A Comprehensive Guide to Making and Eating Delicious Food Wherever You Are|first=Ed|last=Levine|date=1 November 2011|publisher=Clarkson Potter/Publishers|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=De4ronD6qokC&pg=PA102&dq=barbecue+sandwich&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KkJaUbDgKKiQiQKFxYDIBQ&ved=0CEoQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=barbecue+sandwich&f=false|title=Bob Garner's Book of Barbecue: North Carolina's Favorite Food|first=Bob|last=Garner|date=30 March 2018|publisher=John F. Blair, Publisher|via=Google Books}} | [[File:Mmm... home made bbq sauce (5778277654).jpg|120px]] | United States | Served on a [[hamburger bun|bun]], with chopped, sliced, or shredded meat ([[pulled pork]], beef, or chicken typically), and sometimes topped with [[coleslaw]] |- | ''[[Barros Jarpa]]'' | [[File:Barros jarpa 01.jpg|120px]] | [[Chilean cuisine|Chile]] | Ham and cheese, usually ''mantecoso'', which is similar to [[farmer cheese]] |- | ''[[Barros Luco]]'' | [[File:Barros luco 01.jpg|120px]] | Chile | Beef (usually thin-cut steak) and cheese |- | [[Bauru (sandwich)|''Bauru'']] | [[File:Bauru português.jpg|120px]] | [[Brazilian cuisine|Brazil]] | Melted cheese, [[roast beef]], tomato, and pickled cucumber in a hollowed-out [[French roll]] |- | [[Beef on weck]] | [[File:Small - Beef on Weck.jpg|120px]] | [[Cuisine of the United States|United States]]

They can be served with [[provolone]] cheese, long hots (chili peppers) and/or sauteed greens ([[spinach]] or [[rapini|broccoli raab]]). Sometimes they are served Parmesan style, with [[tomato sauce]] and [[mozzarella]] and [[Parmigiano-Reggiano|Parmesan cheese]]. Breaded cutlets ([[schnitzel]]s, [[cotoletta]], or [[escalope]] may have first appeared on the culinary scene with the [[Napoleonic Wars|Napoleonic armies]] for conservation purposes. Napoleon offered a monetary reward to the person who developed a method to transport conserved food for a longer amount of time that then could be consumed unspoiled. Although the breading of meat concept was not the winner, it was a culinary development that was quickly adopted in Austria and northern Italy. |- | [[Dagwood sandwich|Dagwood]] | [[File:Dagwood sandwich.jpg|120px]] | United States | Multiple layers containing a wide variety of meats and condiments, named for [[Dagwood Bumstead]] of the comic strip ''[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]] |- | [[Delicatessen|Deli]] | [[File:Deli Sandwiches.jpg|120px]] | Germany | Sandwich usually ordered at a [[Delicatessen|deli]]; choices include type of bread (toasted or untoasted,) type of meat ([[cold cut]]), type of sliced cheese, vegetable fillings (lettuce, tomato, onion, etc.), and condiments |- | [[Denver sandwich|Denver]] | [[File:Denver sandwich.jpg|120px]] | United States | Sandwich containing a [[Denver omelette#Variations|Denver omelette]] |- | ''[[Doner kebab]]'' | [[File:Döner kebab.jpg|120px]] | [[Turkish cuisine|Turkey]] | Doner kebab is meat cooked on a [[Rotisserie#Vertical rotisserie|vertical spit]], normally [[veal]] or [[beef]] but also may be a mixture of these with [[lamb and mutton|lamb]], and sometimes chicken. This may be served wrapped in a [[flatbread]] such as [[lavash]] or [[pita]], or as a sandwich. |- | [[Donkey Burger|Donkey burger]] | [[File:Donkey burger.jpg|120px]] | [[Chinese cuisine|China]] | Chopped or shredded savory donkey meat in a bun, sold in [[Baoding]], [[Hebei]] Province as [[street food]], and also in high-end restaurants |- | [[Doubles (food)|Doubles]] | [[File:Doubles 01.jpg|120px]] | [[Trinidad and Tobago cuisine|Trinidad and Tobago]] | Two flat fried ''[[Vada (food)|bara]]'' (bread), containing curried [[chickpea]]s or [[Chickpea|garbanzo beans]] |- | [[Dynamite (sandwich)|Dynamite]] | [[File:Dynamite sandwich - 01.jpg|120px]] | United States ([[Woonsocket, Rhode Island]]) | Made of ground beef, tomato sauces, spices and many onions and peppers. The bread is cut horizontally and filled with [[Delicatessen|deli]] ingredients such as [[salami]], [[ham]], [[cheese]], [[mortadella]], or other food, and is sometimes pressed by a warming grill. Retrieved March 4, 2017. | [[File:Pepper-and-egg-sandwich-01.jpg|120px|Pepper and egg sandwich]] | United States ([[Cuisine of Chicago|Chicago]]) | [[Scrambled eggs]] and grilled [[bell pepper]]s, served on [[French bread]]. |- | Pepper and egg, Italian | | Italy and the USA (in areas where there was a concentration of Italian immigrants). | Sauteed Italian long hots, sliced (not diced) in olive oil, (garlic is optional), coated with scrambled eggs and cooked until the eggs are firm. Seasoned with salt and pepper and [[Parmigiano-Reggiano|Parmesan]] or other hard (aged) cheese, such as [[Romano cheese|Romano]] or [[Pecorino]]. Then the mixture is stuffed into an Italian-style roll or between two slices of Italian bread. This may also be served with sliced tomatoes. |- | [[Pimento cheese]] | | [[List of foods of the Southern United States|Southern United States]] | Common food preparation in the [[Cuisine of the Southern United States|Southern United States]], a spread or [[relish]] made with cheese, [[mayonnaise]], [[pimento]]s, [[salt]] and [[Black pepper|pepper]], blended to either a smooth or chunky paste.{{cite web|url=http://deepsouthmag.com/2011/09/pimento-cheese-please/ |title=Pimento Cheese, Please! |website=Deep South Magazine |publisher=Deep South Media |access-date=May 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YXoNKubD?url=http://deepsouthmag.com/2011/09/pimento-cheese-please/ |archivedate=May 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Regional variations incorporate additional ingredients. Also eaten in the United Kingdom (see "Tea" in this list) and the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://panlasangpinoy.com/2013/02/22/cheese-pimiento-sandwich-spread/ |title=Cheese Pimento Sandwich Spread |website=Panlasang Pinoy |access-date=May 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YXoiEQ3F?url=http://panlasangpinoy.com/2013/02/22/cheese-pimiento-sandwich-spread/ |archivedate=May 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |- | ''[[Pistolette]]'' | | | Stuffed and fried bread roll (sometimes called stuffed pistolettes) in the [[Cajun people|Cajun]] areas around [[Lafayette, Louisiana|Lafayette]]. This also refers to a type of submarine-shaped bread about half the size of a baguette that is popular in [[New Orleans]] for Vietnamese [[bánh mì]] and other sandwiches.{{cite book|author=Sari Edelstein|title=Food, Cuisine, and Cultural Competency for Culinary, Hospitality, and Nutrition Professionals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQoWQTVcpVIC&pg=PA60|accessdate=9 September 2012|date=22 October 2010|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers|isbn=978-1-4496-1811-7|pages=60–}} |- | ''[[Pljeskavica]]'' | [[File:Pljeskavica sandwich.jpg|120px]] | [[Balkan cuisine|Balkans]] | [[Patty]] dish popular in the [[Balkans|Balkan region]] of Southeastern Europe, a sandwich utilizes the Pljeskavica patty and bread. |- | [[Po' boy]] | [[File:Shrimppoboy.jpg|120px]] | United States | Crusty long roll split and filled with cold cuts, roasted beef or fried seafood. The New Orleans analogue to the sub or hoagie. |- | [[Polish boy]] | [[File:Polish boy.jpg|120px]] | United States ([[Cleveland#Cuisine|Cleveland, Ohio]]) | [[Kielbasa]] sausage in a bun, covered with [[french fries]], [[barbecue sauce]] (or hot sauce), and [[coleslaw]]. |- | [[Porchetta]] | [[File:Porchetta Sandwich.jpg|120px]] | Italy | A sandwich made of roast pork with italian-type spices such as rosemary, garlic, fennel and others in varying proportions. It is popular as street food (usually sold from white trucks) throughout central Italy. It was transplanted to America in the late 19th century by Italian immigrants and is known as the "roast" pork sandwich, very popular in the northeastern United States. In America it is often served with [[provolone]] cheese and "greens" which may be [[spinach]] or [[rapini|broccoli raab]]. |- | ''[[Porilainen]]'' | [[File:Porilainen.jpg|120px]] | [[Finnish cuisine|Finland]] | Half-inch slice of thick sausage, usually with diced red or sweet onion, sliced pickles, ketchup, mustard, and sometimes mayonnaise, on white bread. |- | [[Pork chop bun]] | [[File:Porkchopbun.jpg|120px]] | Macau | Popular dish in Macau, the [[bun]] is extremely crisp outside and very soft inside, containing a freshly fried [[pork chop]]. |- | [[Pork tenderloin sandwich|Pork tenderloin]] | [[File:Pork tenderloin sandwich.JPG|120px]] | United States Midwest | Thin, tenderized, deep-fried pork loin, served on a bun. |- | [[Prawn roll]] | | [[Australian cuisine|Australia]] | |- | Prego | [[File:Prego no prato at Cafe Vianna Braga (5711629526).jpg|120px]] | Portugal | These steaks flavored with onions and red wine are called prego (nailed) steaks because a small meat mallet is typically used to nail the garlic slices into the steak. The [[marination|marinade]] is red wine based and includes onions, the aforementioned garlic, chilies, bay leaf, parsley, oregano, ground black pepper and olive oil. The steak is grilled and placed in Portuguese rolls called carcaças. A reduced marinade based sauce is drizzled over the meats. |- | [[Primanti]] | [[File:Primanti Bros at PNC Park.jpg|120px]] | [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], United States | Selection of grilled meats topped with french fries, coleslaw, and tomato on Italian bread. |- | [[Prosperity Sandwich]] | | United States ([[St. Louis]]) | Ham and turkey topped with broiled cheese. Sometimes includes bacon and tomato. |- | Pudgy pie{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4GkiAQAAMAAJ&q=Pudgy+Pie+sandwich&dq=Pudgy+Pie+sandwich&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JkRaUefdJcbliwKJ6oHoBg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwAw|title=The New Yorker|date=1 June 1949|publisher=New Yorker Magazine, Incorporated|via=Google Books}} | | United States | Sandwich made in a pan, with margarine on the outside, and either savory, with pizza sauce and other fillings on the inside, or sweet containing pie filling. The term "pudgy pie" is sometimes used to refer to pie irons, a gadget used for campfire cooking.[https://books.google.com/books?id=vJBCbUEs37IC&pg=PA156&dq=pudgy+pie&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cS5dUeiHGsbBigLMkYDwCA&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=pudgy%20pie&f=false Campground Cookery: Great Recipes for Any Outdoor Activity - Brenda Kulibert - Google Books]. p. 156.[https://books.google.com/books?id=FQ4zelVNRXsC&pg=PT173&dq=pudgy+pie&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cS5dUeiHGsbBigLMkYDwCA&ved=0CGMQ6AEwBw Camping with Kids: The Complete Guide to Car, Tent, and RV Camping - Goldie Gendler Silverman - Google Books] p. 160. |- | [[Pulled pork sandwich|Pulled pork]] | [[File:Pulled pork BBQ sandwich.jpg|120px]] | [[Cuisine of the Southern United States|Southern United States]] | [[Barbecue]] sandwich in which [[pork]] (usually shoulder) is smoked slowly at a low temperature until the meat becomes tender enough that it can be "pulled" or shredded with two forks. The pork is served on a bun and often topped with [[barbecue sauce]] and [[vinegar]]- or [[mayonnaise]]-based [[coleslaw]] depending on the region. |- | [[Alexandra of Denmark|Queen Alexandra]]'s sandwich | | [[Cuisine of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] | Chicken, mayonnaise, boiled tongue and cress |- | [[Reuben sandwich|Reuben]] | [[File:Katz's Deli - Lunch.jpg|120px]] | United States (Omaha, Nebraska) | [[Corned beef]], [[sauerkraut]], Swiss cheese, topped with [[Russian dressing|Russian]] or [[Thousand Island dressing]], on [[rye bread]], then grilled. |- | [[Roast beef sandwich|Roast beef]] | [[File:Arbysbeefandfries.JPG|120px]] | | Sliced [[roast beef]] or sometimes [[meatloaf|beef loaf]] on bread. A variant of this sandwich is the roast beef special (deli sandwich) which is sliced roast beef, thousand island salad dressing and cole slaw served, generally, on rye bread. |- | ''[[Roti john]]'' | [[File:Roti John - served.jpg|120px]] | [[Southeast Asian cuisine|Southeast Asia]] | Basic ingredients are eggs, chopped onions, sambal paste, salt, and pepper, cooked as an omelette with the bread added on top before it's fully cooked. Many variations include canned sardines, chicken, beef, or mutton. Garnished with mayo, chili sauce, and cheese. |- | ''[[Rou jia mo]]'' | [[File:Roujiamo.jpg|120px]] | China | Stewed pork, chopped finely, and stuffed in ''mo'', a kind of [[flatbread]]. |- |[[Finnish bread|Ruisleipä]] |[[File:Winning combination.png|125x125px]] |[[Finland]] |Sandwich made of traditional Finnish dark rye, buttered, with lettuce, hard-boiled egg, pickles, tomato, and choice of cheese and meat (typically pork). The fillings are baked inside the bread, similar to a kolache. Popular in the Midwestern United States, especially Nebraska. |- | [[Sabich]] | [[File:Sabich.jpg|120px]] | Israel | Pita stuffed with fried aubergine, sliced hard boiled egg, tahini sauce and [[Israeli salad]], among other ingredients. |- | [[Sailor sandwich|Sailor]] | [[File:2015 0629 Sailor at NYD.jpg|120px]] | United States ([[Richmond, Virginia]]) | Hot [[pastrami]], grilled [[knockwurst]], melted [[Swiss]] and [[hot mustard]] on [[rye bread]].{{cite web |url=http://www.richmond.com/entertainment/article_9d476505-ada6-56e1-85da-c10c00cbf560.html |title=Richmond's Very Own Sandwich |newspaper=Richmond Times-Dispatch |date=September 15, 2010 |author=Anika Imajo |accessdate=July 1, 2015 |quote="The brazen assemblage of hot pastrami, grilled knockwurst, melted Swiss and hot mustard on rye bread, curiously known in these parts as a "sailor sandwich" is, most likely, a true Richmond native. It was developed at McNally's Tavern in Chestnut Hill in the 1960s in response to a favored sandwich of a friend and co-worker of the proprietor's husband. It is named after [[Christian Schmidt Brewing Company|Schmidt's beer]] with which it was served. The filling consists of grilled beef steak and onions topped with grilled cooked or cotto [[salami]], American cheese and tomato. It is topped with a sauce consisting of [[mayonnaise]], sweet pickle [[relish]], [[ketchup]] and [[Worcestershire sauce]] served on a kaiser roll. |- | [[Sealed crustless sandwich|Sealed crustless]] | [[File:Smucker's Uncrustable Cut - Day 26 of 100 Project (8126561088).jpg|120px]] | [[United States]] | The filling in this sandwich is sealed between two layers of bread by a crimped edge and has the crust subsequently removed. Smucker Company under the brand name "Uncrustables". |- | ''[[Shawarma]]'' | [[File:Flickr - cyclonebill - Shawarma (1).jpg|120px]] | [[Levant|The Levant]] | Flatbread with fillings of beef, spinach, tomatoes, cucumber, and tahini sauce, wrapped and grilled. |- |[[Shooter's sandwich]] |[[File:Shooter's sandwich.jpg|120px]] |England |Prepared by filling a hollowed-out long loaf of bread with cooked filet mignon steak, cooked mushrooms, salt and pepper.{{cite book | last=Wilson | first=B. | title=Sandwich: A Global History | publisher=Reaktion Books | series=Edible | year=2010 | isbn=978-1-86189-891-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ydR5na_9fnYC&pg=PP61 | accessdate=April 14, 2017 | page=61}}{{cite book | last=David | first=E. | last2=O'Neill | first2=M. | title=Summer Cooking | publisher=New York Review Books | series=New York Review Books classics | year=1955 | isbn=978-1-59017-004-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjm_stfGEaoC&pg=PA212 | accessdate=April 14, 2017 | page=212}} |- | Shuco | | Guatemala | Dry hot dog bun containing guacamole, sliced cabbage, ketchup, mustard and mayonnaise. In the United Kingdom it is named a [[baguette]], after the French bread used to make it. |- | [[Pork roll|Taylor Ham or Pork roll Sandwich]] | [[File:Pork roll egg cheese sand readytoeat.JPG|120px]] | New Jersey | Pork roll still is the predominant term in South Jersey, but in the northern part of the state it is “Taylor Ham”https://www.northjersey.com/story/life/columnists/2018/03/06/taylor-ham-pork-roll-food-item-shaped-our-nation/396114002/. It is grilled pork roll served several ways. This can be served with a fried egg, or a fried egg with cheese. Variations include serving with grilled pork roll and cheese or just grilled pork roll. The sandwich is often toasted in a sandwich press. |- | [[Tuna fish sandwich|Tuna]] | [[File:Tuna olive and avocado sandwich.jpg|120px]] | United States | Usually made with [[tuna salad]], which may include [[mayonnaise]], [[sweetcorn]], [[cucumber]], or [[celery]]. Other common variations include the '''tuna boat''' and '''tuna melt'''. |- | ''[[Vada pav]]'' | [[File:Jumbo Vada Pav (dodged).jpg|120px]] | [[Indian cuisine|India]] | Potato fritter coated in chickpea flour (''[[batata vada]]'') in a bun[http://www.haftamag.com/2006/10/16/deconstructing-the-pav-bhaji-2/ Hafta Magazine: ''Deconstructing the Pav Bhaji''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105210646/http://www.haftamag.com/2006/10/16/deconstructing-the-pav-bhaji-2/ |date=2009-01-05 }} |- | [[Vegemite]] | [[File:Vegemiteontoast large.jpg|120px]] | [[Australian cuisine|Australia]] | Vegemite is a dark brown Australian food paste made from used brewers' [[yeast extract]], a [[by-product]] of [[Brewing (beer)|beer manufacturing]], various vegetables, wheat, and spice additives. It is a [[Spread (food)|spread]] for sandwiches, [[toast]], [[crumpet]]s, and [[cracker (food)|cracker biscuits]], as well as a filling for pastries. |- | [[Vegetable sandwich|Vegetable]] | [[File:Vegetable sandwich.jpg|120px]] | India | Many types of [[vegetable]]s are used to prepare vegetable sandwiches. |- | ''[[Wurstbrot]]'' (sausage bread) | [[File:Sandwich wurstbrot-wurstbroetchen 2871.JPG|120px]] | [[German cuisine|Germany]] | Simple and common German sandwich prepared with thin slices of [[lunch meat]] or [[sausage]], sometimes buttered. |- | [[Yakisoba|''Yakisoba-pan'']] | [[File:Yakisoba sandwich by kaex0r.jpg|120px]] | Japan | Hot dog bun stuffed with fried noodles, frequently topped with [[Pickled cucumber|pickle]]s, such as ''[[beni shōga]], with mayonnaise |- | ''[[Zapiekanka]]'' | [[File:Polish "Zapiekanka".jpg|120px]] | [[Polish cuisine|Poland]] | Halved baguette or other bread usually topped with mushrooms and cheese, ham or other meats, and vegetables |- | ''[[Zsíroskenyér]]'' |[[File:Zsíros kenyér, 3.jpg|120px]] | [[Hungary]] | Lard on white bread, usually topped with white or red onion slices |} ==See also== {{Commons category|Sandwiches}} * [[Hot dog variations]] * [[List of American sandwiches]] * [[List of bread dishes]] * [[List of hamburgers]] * [[List of submarine sandwich restaurants]] * [[Sandwich bread]] * [[Soup and sandwich]] {{Subject bar|portal1=Food|portal2=Lists}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Sandwiches}} {{Lists of prepared foods}} [[Category:Sandwiches|*]] [[Category:World cuisine|Sandwiches]] [[Category:Lists of foods by type|sandwiches]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=November 2015}} This is a list of '''[[territorial dispute]]s''' over lands around the world, both past and in modern times. '''Bold''' indicates one claimant's full control; ''italics'' indicates one or more claimants' partial control. {{Expand list|date=July 2017}} ==Ongoing disputes between UN member states== ===Africa=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Territory ! Claimants ! Notes |- | [[Abyei]], [[Heglig Crisis|Heglig]], Jodha, [[Kafia Kingi]] and Kaka | '''{{SDN}}'''
{{SSD}} | Both Sudan and South Sudan have claimed the area after the civil war that led to South Sudan's independence. Heglig was controlled by South Sudan in mid-April 2012 but retaken by Sudan. Abyei was taken in May 2012. |- | [[Banc du Geyser]] | ''{{MDG}}''
''{{COM}}''
''{{flagu|France}}'' | France claims the reef as part of the [[Scattered Islands in the Indian Ocean]], a district of the [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]]. |- | [[Bassas da India]], [[Europa Island]] and [[Juan de Nova Island]] | '''{{flagu|France}}'''
{{MDG}}[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2070.html Field Listing - Disputes - international], ''[[The World Factbook]]'' | ''De facto'' part of the French territory of [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]]. |- | [[Ceuta]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/|title=Breaking News, World News & Multimedia|publisher=|accessdate=30 June 2017}} [[Melilla]], other [[plazas de soberanía]] | '''{{flagu|Spain}}'''
{{MAR}} | Ceuta and Melilla are administered by Spain as autonomous cities. An incident on Perejil Island happened in 2002, after which both countries agreed to return to ''[[status quo]]''.[http://www.mae.es/NR/rdonlyres/E53D6D9A-03FF-49C9-9174-F96473692B2A/0/J.pdf Comunicados y notas de prensa de la OID] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030140/http://www.mae.es/NR/rdonlyres/E53D6D9A-03FF-49C9-9174-F96473692B2A/0/J.pdf|date=September 27, 2007}} |- | [[Chagos Archipelago]] | '''{{flagu|United Kingdom}}'''
{{MUS}} | United Kingdom administers the archipelago as part of the [[British Indian Ocean Territory]]. |- | Doumeira Mountain and [[Doumeira Island]] | '''{{flagu|Eritrea}}'''
{{DJI}} | Basis of the [[Djiboutian–Eritrean border conflict]] of 2008. Disputed territory occupied by Eritrea following withdrawal of Qatari peacekeepers in June 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-djibouti-eritrea-border-idUSKBN1971JR |publisher=[[Reuters]] |title=Djibouti, Eritrea in territorial dispute after Qatar peacekeepers leave |first=Aaron |last=Maasho |editor-first=James |editor-last=Dalgleish |date=June 16, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.janes.com/article/71617/eritrea-s-alleged-seizure-of-disputed-djiboutian-territory-increases-likelihood-of-miscalculation-leading-to-military-escalation |publisher=[[Jane's Information Group]] |first=Chris |last=Suckling |title=Eritrea's alleged seizure of disputed Djiboutian territory increases likelihood of miscalculation leading to military escalation |quote=Djibouti's foreign minister, Mahamoud Ali Youssouf, alleged in a televised address on 16 June that Eritrean forces had occupied the disputed Dumaira Mountains, immediately after Qatar withdrew a 500-strong contingent of peacekeepers without notification on 14 June.}} Alternatively transliterated as the Dumaira Mountains. |- | [[Glorioso Islands]] | '''{{flagu|France}}'''
{{MDG}}
{{COM}} | ''De facto'' part of the French territory of [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]]. |- | [[Hala'ib Triangle]] and [[Bir Tawil]] |''{{EGY}}''
{{SDN}}{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3120/is_200407/ai_n7779206 |title=Why are Egypt and Sudan in dispute over the Hala'ib Triangle?(Quizzical)(Brief Article) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113145252/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3120/is_200407/ai_n7779206 |archivedate=2007-11-13 |df= }} | Previously under joint administration; Egypt now maintains full ''de facto'' control of the Hala'ib Triangle. The boundaries Egypt and Sudan claim to get the Hala'ib Triangle both leave out Bir Tawil, resulting in Bir Tawil being a ''de jure'' and ''de facto'' no man's land. |- | [[Ilemi Triangle]] | '''{{KEN}}'''
{{SSD}} |''De facto'' controlled by Kenya. Ethiopian tribes have used and made raids in the land, but the Ethiopian government has never made a claim to it, agreeing it was Sudanese in 1902, 1907 and 1972 treaties.{{Cite book|title=African Boundaries: A Legal and Diplomatic Encyclopedia|last=[[Ian Brownlie|Brownlie]]|first=[[Ian Brownlie|Ian]]|publisher=Institute for International Affairs, Hurst and Co.|year=1979|pages=867–884; 917–921}}{{Cite book|url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/ethio_0066-2127_2004_num_20_1_1065|title=The Ilemi Triangle in: Annales d'Éthiopie. Volume 20, année 2004|last=Collins|first=Robert O.|year=2004|pages=5–12|accessdate=2011-06-17}}The [[National Geographic Society]] in recent works has included an Ethiopian claim, later removed due to lack of sources. The [[World Factbook]] confirms that Ethiopia does not claim the territory |- | [[KaNgwane]] | '''{{ZAF}}'''
{{SWZ}} | Eswatini claims territories which it states were confiscated during colonial times.{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/Report/44343/ESWATINI-Land-claim-falls-on-deaf-SA-ears|title=ESWATINI: Land claim falls on deaf SA ears|website=IRIN|date=June 16, 2003|accessdate=March 7, 2012}} The area claimed by Eswatini is the former [[bantustan]] of [[KaNgwane]], which now forms the northern parts of [[Jozini Local Municipality|Jozini]] and [[uMhlabuyalingana Local Municipality|uMhlabuyalingana]] local municipalities in [[KwaZulu-Natal]], and the southern part of [[Nkomazi Local Municipality|Nkomazi]], the southeastern part of [[Umjindi Local Municipality|Umjindi]] and the far eastern part of [[Albert Luthuli Local Municipality|Albert Luthuli]] local municipalities in [[Mpumalanga]]. |- | [[Koualou]] village and surrounding area | {{BFA}}'''
'''{{BEN}} |Burkina Faso and Benin retain a border dispute at this 68 km2 triangular area of land near the tripoint border with [[Togo]].{{Cite web|url=http://lefaso.net/spip.php?article31781|title=Différend frontalier Burkina-Bénin : Kourou/Koalou déclarée zone (...) - leFaso.net, l'actualité au Burkina Faso|website=lefaso.net|language=fr|access-date=2017-10-12}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/print_bn.html|title=CIA World Factbook – Benin|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=12 October 2017}} In a 2008 meeting, it was declared that the territory was a neutral zone, neither Burkinabé nor Beninese. According to the UN Refugee Agency in 2015, there were issues of children being born stateless in the area, however a Beninese civil registration office has taken control of registering births in the area.{{Cite web|url=https://data2.unhcr.org/ar/documents/download/54204|title=UNHCR Newsletter – January–August 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|page=5|access-date=12 October 2017}} |- | Kpéaba village area (near [[Sipilou]]/Siquita) | '''{{CIV}}'''
{{GIN}} | The Guinean military occupied this village for 1 month from January to February 2013, before withdrawing in preparation of talks.{{cite news|title=Guinea, Cote d'Ivoire Border Dispute Reportedly Resurfaces |url=http://guineenews.org/2014/03/le-conflit-frontalier-entre-la-guinee-et-la-cote-divoire-autour-de-kpeaba-refait-surface/ |work=Guinee News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308072638/http://guineenews.org/2014/03/le-conflit-frontalier-entre-la-guinee-et-la-cote-divoire-autour-de-kpeaba-refait-surface/ |archivedate=2014-03-08 |df= }} In December 2016, Guinea soldiers and civilians attacked the village, killing 1 and wounding several others, before returning to their side of the border.{{Cite news|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/387125/politique/cote-divoire-civil-tue-militaires-guineens-a-kpeaba-louest-pays/|title=Côte d’Ivoire : un civil tué par des militaires guinéens à Kpéaba dans l’ouest du pays, la Guinée dément – JeuneAfrique.com|date=2016-12-23|work=JeuneAfrique.com|access-date=2017-10-12|language=fr-FR}} According to the Guinean Minister of Defence, the Guinean army had been asked not to send any soldiers to this area and had no involvement in this incident.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20161223-cote-ivoire-guinee-kpeaba-attaque-civil-soldat-militaire-ministre|title=Côte d'Ivoire/Guinée: un ancien litige frontalier ressurgit à Kpéaba - RFI|work=RFI Afrique|access-date=2017-10-12|language=fr-FR}} |- | Area near [[Logoba]]/[[Moyo District]] | '''{{SSD}}'''
'''{{UGA}}''' |{{Cite news|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/OpEd/Commentary/Uganda--South-Sudan-should-urgently-settle-border-dispute/689364-2464086-10jmv5f/index.html|title=Uganda, South Sudan should urgently settle border dispute|work=Daily Monitor|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-UK}} |- | Border near [[Chiengi]], [[Luapula Province border dispute|Lunchinda-Pweto Province]] | '''{{ZMB}}'''
{{flag|Democratic Republic of Congo}} |Dormant dispute.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} |- | [[Mayotte]] | '''{{flagu|France}}'''
{{COM}} | Under the [[Mahoran status referendum, 2009|2009 referendum]], the population supported becoming an overseas department of France, and so became one on March 31, 2011. |- | Islands in [[Mbamba Bay]], [[Lake Nyasa]] | '''{{TZA}}'''
{{MWI}} | Lundo Is. and Mbambo Is. are claimed as part of the lake, as Malawi claims to the shore based on 1890 Anglo-German treaty. See [[Lake Malawi#Tanzania–Malawi dispute]]. |- | [[Mbañie Island]], [[Cocotiers]] and [[Congas Island]] | {{GAB}}
{{GNQ}} |Contested islands in [[Corisco Bay]], valuable for their oil.''[http://www.senat.fr/ga/ga53/ga532.html Compte rendu du déplacement d'une délégation du groupe interparlementaire France-Afrique centrale au Gabon, en Guinée équatoriale et à Sao Tomé-et-Principe]'', parliamentary report of the [[Senate of France]], 2003.{{Cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/news/2004/01/23/un-mediates-dispute-over-corisco-bay-islands|title=UN mediates dispute over Corisco Bay islands|date=2004-01-23|work=IRIN|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en}} |- | [[Migingo Island]] vicinity, and, farther north, the vicinity of the islands of [[Lolwe]], [[Oyasi]], [[Remba]], [[Ringiti]] and [[Sigulu]], all a maritime rights dispute in [[Lake Victoria]]. | '''{{KEN}}'''
'''{{UGA}}''' | |- | Several islands in the [[Congo River]] | '''{{COG}}'''
'''{{flag|Democratic Republic of Congo}}''' | |- | Several islands in the [[Ntem River]] | '''{{CMR}}'''
'''{{GNQ}}''' |- | Several villages near the [[Okpara River]] | '''{{BEN}}'''
'''{{NGA}}''' | |- | [[Orange River]] border line | {{NAM}}
{{SAF}} | Namibia claims the border lies along the middle of the river, while South Africa claims it lies along the north bank. |- | [[Djiboutian–Eritrean border conflict|Ras Doumeira and Doumeira Island]] | '''{{ERI}}'''
{{DJI}} | |- | The [[Rufunzo Valley]] and [[Sabanerwa]] | '''{{RWA}}'''
'''{{BDI}}''' | |- | [[Rukwanzi Island]] and the [[Semliki River]] valley | '''{{flag|Democratic Republic of Congo}}'''
'''{{UGA}}''' | |- | [[Sindabezi Island]] | '''{{ZMB}}'''
{{ZWE}}{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=IDE5DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA190&lpg=PA190&dq=sindabezi+island+dispute#v=onepage&q=sindabezi%20island%20dispute&f=false | title=The Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the European Union (EU): Regionalism and External Influence| isbn=9783319453309| last1=Muntschick| first1=Johannes| date=2017-10-09}} | |- | [[Socotra|Socotran Archipelago]] | '''{{YEM}}'''
'''{{SOM}}''' | Somalia, while not formally claiming the archipelago, asked for the [[United Nations]] to look into "the status" of the Socotran archipelago (i.e., whether or not it "should" belong to Yemen or rather Somalia).{{cite web|url=http://www.hiiraan.com/news2/2010/oct/for_first_time_in_history_somalia_claims_socotra_as_its_own.aspx|title=For First Time in History, Somalia Claims Socotra as Its Own|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2014}} |- | [[Tromelin Island]] | '''{{flagu|France}}'''
{{MUS}}
| ''De facto'' part of the French territory of [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]]. |- | [[Wadi Halfa]] Salient | '''{{EGY}}'''
{{SDN}} | |} ===Asia=== [[File:South China Sea claims map.jpg|thumb|250px|Territorial claims in the South China Sea]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Territory ! Claimants ! Notes |- |[[Ashmore and Cartier Islands]] |'''{{Flag|Australia}}'''
{{Flag|Indonesia}} |Indonesia argues that the islands, known in Indonesian as ''Kepulauan Pasir'', were first discovered and inhabited by local fishermen from [[Lesser Sunda Islands]], which were then part of [[Dutch East Indies]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/indian-ocean/ai.htm|title=Ashmore and Cartier Islands [AU]|last=Pike|first=John|website=www.globalsecurity.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-14}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.antaranews.com/berita/43871/fakta-sejarah-tunjukkan-pulau-pasir-milik-indonesia|title=Fakta Sejarah Tunjukkan Pulau Pasir Milik Indonesia - ANTARA News|last=antaranews.com|work=Antara News|access-date=2018-01-14|language=id-ID}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.merdeka.com/politik/pengakuan-kepemilikan-australia-atas-pulau-pasir-masih-lemah-39c4tjh.html|title=Pengakuan Kepemilikan Australia Atas Pulau Pasir Masih Lemah {{!}} merdeka.com|last=Merdeka.com|work=merdeka.com|access-date=2018-01-14|language=en}} |- | [[Arsal|Aarsal]], [[Deir El Aachayer]], [[Kfar Qouq]], [[Mazraat Deir al-Ashayer]], [[Qaa]], [[Qasr, Lebanon|Qasr]] and [[Tuffah, Lebanon|Tuffah]] | '''{{LBN}}'''
{{SYR}} | |- | [[Abu Musa]] | {{nowrap|'''{{IRN}}'''
{{ARE}}}} | |- | [[Nagorno-Karabakh|Nagorno-Karabakh region]] and [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh|seven adjacent districts]] | ''{{flag|Artsakh}}''
{{ARM}}
''{{AZE}}'' | Internationally recognized as part of [[Azerbaijan]],{{cite web | url =https://www.un.org/press/en/2008/ga10693.doc.htm|title=General Assembly adopts resolution reaffirming territorial integrity of Azerbaijan, demanding withdrawal of all Armenian forces|publisher=United Nations| date=14 March 2008| accessdate =23 Dec 2016}} de facto controlled by the [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] supported by [[Armenia]]. |- | [[Bhutanese enclaves]] in [[Tibet]], namely [[Cherkip Gompa]], [[Dho (Tibet)|Dho]], [[Dungmar]], [[Gesur]], [[Gezon]], [[Itse Gompa]], [[Khochar]], [[Nyanri]], [[Ringung]], [[Sanmar]], [[Darchen|Tarchen]], [[Doklam]] and [[Zuthulphuk]] | '''{{PRC}}'''
{{BTN}}
| |- | [[Gilgit Baltistan]] & [[Azad Kashmir]] |'''{{flagicon|Pakistan}} [[Pakistan]]'''
{{flagicon|India}} [[India]] | Administrated by Pakistan and claimed by India. Part of the [[Kashmir conflict]]. |- | [[Hatay Province]] | '''{{TUR}}'''
{{SYR}} | Territory annexed by Turkey in 1939, ceded from Syria under the [[French Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon|French Mandate of Syria]]; the annexation was never formally recognized by Syria after its independence. |- | [[Jammu & Kashmir]] |'''{{flagicon|India}} [[India]]'''
{{flagicon|Pakistan}} [[Pakistan]] |Part of the [[Kashmir conflict]]. Both India and Pakistan claim the former princely state of [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|Jammu and Kashmir]], leading to the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1947]]. A UN-mediated ceasefire put a halt to the conflict in January 1949. The UN resolution called for both the countries to demilitarise the region, following which a plebiscite would be held. However, no demilitarisation plan acceptable to both the countries could be agreed. The countries fought two further wars in [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|1965]] and [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|1971]]. Following the latter war, the countries reached the [[Simla Agreement]], agreeing on a [[Line of Control]] between their respective regions and committing to a peaceful resolution of the dispute through [[India-Pakistan relations|bilateral negotiations]]. An [[Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir|armed insurgency]] broke out in 1989 in the Indian administered part of Kashmir, demanding "independence". Pakistan is [[Pakistan and state sponsored terrorism|believed to provide arms]] and training to the insurgents. {{citation |last=Korbel |first=Josef |authorlink=Josef Korbel |title=Danger in Kashmir |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=1966}} {{citation |first=Victoria |last=Schofield |authorlink=Victoria Schofield |title=Kashmir in Conflict |publisher=I. B. Taurus & Co |location=London and New York |year=2003 |origyear=First published in 2000 |isbn=978-1860648984 }} {{citation |first=Sumantra |last=Bose |authorlink=Sumantra Bose |title=Kashmir: Roots of Conflict, Paths to Peace |publisher=Harvard University Press |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-674-01173-1}} {{citation |last=Varshney |first=Ashutosh |authorlink=Ashutosh Varshney |chapter=Three Compromised Nationalisms: Why Kashmir has been a Problem |editor=Raju G. C. Thomas |title=Perspectives on Kashmir: the roots of conflict in South Asia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrPtAAAAMAAJ |year=1992 |publisher=Westview Press |isbn=978-0-8133-8343-9 |pp=191–234|chapterurl=https://apps.cndls.georgetown.edu/courses/rudolph/g238/files/Varshney-_1992-Why-Kashmir.pdf}} |- |- | Various areas: [[Dak Jerman]]/[[Dak Duyt]], [[Dak Dang]]/[[Dak Huyt]], the [[La Drang]] area and the islands of [[Baie]]/[[Koh Ta Kiev]], [[Milieu (Vietnam)|Milieu]]/[[Koh Thmey]], [[Eau (Vietnam)|Eau]]/[[Koh Ses]], [[Pic (Vietnam)|Pic]]/[[Koh Thonsáy]] | '''{{KHM}}'''
'''{{VNM}}''' | |- | [[David Gareja monastery complex]] boundary dispute | '''{{GEO}}'''
'''{{AZE}}''' | |- | [[Demchok]], [[Chumar]], [[Kaurik]], [[Shipki La|Shipki Pass]], [[Jadh]], and [[Lapthal]] |'''{{IND}}'''
{{PRC}}
| Disputed areas located between [[Aksai Chin]] and [[Nepal]]. |- | [[Doi Pha Hom Pok National Park|Doi Lang]] | '''{{MYA}}'''
{{THA}} | |- | [[Fasht Ad Dibal]] and [[Qit'at Jaradah]] | '''{{BHR}}'''
'''{{QAT}}''' | These were not included in the 2001 [[International Court of Justice]] judgement, as low-tide elevations. |- | Several areas in the [[Fergana Valley]] | '''{{KGZ}}'''
'''{{TJK}}'''
'''{{UZB}}''' | [[Kyrgyzstan]]: A tiny Kyrgyz village, Barak, in the Fergana Valley region (where Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan meet) is bordered on the north, west and south by Uzbekistan. [[Tajikistan]]: There are three Tajik exclaves, all of them in the Fergana Valley. One of them, the village of Sarvan, is surrounded by Uzbek territory, whereas the remaining two, the village of Vorukh and a small settlement near the Kyrgyz railway station of Kairagach, are each surrounded by Kyrgyz territory. [[Uzbekistan]]: There are four Uzbek exclaves, all inside Kyrgyz territory in the Fergana Valley. Two of them are the towns of Sokh and Shakhimardan and the other two the tiny territories of Chong-Kara and Dzhangail. There may be a fifth Uzbek exclave inside of Kyrgyzstan.[http://cominganarchy.com/2005/12/23/enclaves-iii-the-fergana-valley/ Enclaves III: The Fergana Valley] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017233031/http://cominganarchy.com/2005/12/23/enclaves-iii-the-fergana-valley/ |date=October 17, 2013 }} Most of the border in the area is still not demarcated. |- | [[Golan sub-district|Western]] [[Golan Heights]] | '''{{ISR}}'''
{{SYR}} | Syrian territory captured by Israel in 1967 (the Six-Day War), and unilaterally annexed by Israel in 1981. In 2008, a plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly voted by 161–1 in favor of a motion on the "occupied Syrian Golan" that reaffirmed support for UN Resolution 497; United Nations, December 5, 2008). During the Syrian civil war period, Syrian Arab Republic had lost direct control of the Eastern Golan areas and retreated from cease-fire line with Israel (in favor of various rebel and Jihadist groups), though did regain the area in 2018. |- | [[Greater and Lesser Tunbs]] | '''{{IRN}}'''
{{ARE}} | |- | [[Isfara Valley]] | '''{{KGZ}}'''
{{TJK}} | |- | [[Ambalat]] | '''{{IDN}}'''
'''{{MYS}}''' | |- | 24-mile stretch of border at pass of the [[Kabaw Valley|Kabaw]][https://www.dur.ac.uk/ibru/news/boundary_news/?itemno=28745&rehref=%2Fibru%2Fnews%2F&resubj=Boundary+news+Headlines Myanmar aims to complete border demarcation]. IBRU Boundary News, August 22, 2016. Retrieved January 9, 2017. | {{IND}}
{{MMR}} | |- | [[Kalapani, territory|Kalapani]] region, the smaller [[Susta|Susta River]] dispute and the smaller still [[Antudanda]] and [[Nawalparasi]] disputes | '''{{flagicon|India}} [[India]] '''
{{flagicon|Nepal}} [[Nepal]] |All administered by India. See [[Territorial disputes of India and Nepal]]. |- | [[Artsvashen]] exclave of [[Gegharkunik province]], de jure part of Armenia; [[Karki, Azerbaijan|Karki]] exclave of [[Nakhichevan Autonomous Republic]], [[Yuxarı Əskipara|Yukhari Askipara]] and [[Barkhudarli]], both exclaves of [[Qazakh Rayon]] de jure part of Azerbaijan; "[[Yaradullu]]" is controlled by Azerbaijan along with occupying the much larger de jure Armenian territory surrounding it. | ''{{ARM}}''
''{{AZE}}'' | Azerbaijan and Armenia have controlled these areas as part of the wider [[Nagorno-Karabakh War|Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict]]. |- | [[James Shoal]] | '''{{MYS}}'''
{{PRC}} | |- | [[Khuriya Muriya Islands]] | '''{{OMN}}'''
{{YEM}} | |- | [[Korean Peninsula]] ([[Korea]]) | ''{{PRK}}''
''{{KOR}}'' | The Democratic People's Republic of Korea administers North Korea, but Article 1 of the [[s:Constitution of North Korea (1972)|Constitution of North Korea]] reads: "The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is an independent socialist State representing the interests of all the Korean people." The Republic of Korea administers South Korea, but Article 3 of the [[s:Constitution of South Korea|Constitution of South Korea]] reads: "The territory of the Republic of Korea shall consist of the Korean peninsula and its adjacent islands." |- | [[Kula Kangri]] and mountainous areas to the west of this peak, plus the western [[Haa District]] of [[Bhutan]] | '''{{PRC}}'''
{{BTN}} | Possibly also the ROC.The [[Republic of China]] (ROC), now based in [[Geography of Taiwan|Taiwan]], is involved in territorial disputes with many governments bordering mainland China. Due to the [[One-China policy]], it has no formal diplomatic relations with any of these states. The ROC recognizes neither the [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC) nor its border agreements or treaties with any other countries. Article 4 of the [[Constitution of the Republic of China]] states that "The territory of the Republic of China according to its existing national boundaries shall not be altered except by resolution of the National Assembly." Section 5 of Article 4 of the [[wikisource:Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China|Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China]] now overrides this provision, with the power of the National Assembly to alter transferred to the Legislative Yuan and the electorate. |- | South [[Kuril Islands]] (Northern Territories) | '''{{flagu|Russia}}'''

{{UKR}} | Since 2001 Russia delays an establishment of the border with Ukraine.Woronowycz, R. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20141104223634/http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2001/470103.shtml Ukraine and Russia move on border delimitation].'' Kyiv Press Bureau. "[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]". 25 November 2001 |- | [[Tuzla Island]] and [[Strait of Kerch]]; [[Sarych]] | The conflict arose in 2003 when the Russian authorities started to build a dam towards the island. Since then Ukraine established a border garrison on the island for a closer surveillance. The reason for the conflict is the fact that Tuzla island's strategic location gives Ukraine full rights over the main channel in the Strait of Kerch and, thus, the access to the [[Sea of Azov]]. The conflict is based on the division of the [[Black Sea Fleet]] and a lease agreement of the Sevastopol Naval facilities. |- | [[Sea of Azov]] | ("Mutual jurisdiction")[http://people.ucalgary.ca/~amcewen/Azov-Kerch.pdf RUSSIA RUSSIA ––UKRAINE BOUNDARY IN THE UKRAINE BOUNDARY IN THE SEA OF AZOV AND KERCH STRAIT SEA OF AZOV AND KERCH STRAIT] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514090446/http://people.ucalgary.ca/~amcewen/Azov-Kerch.pdf |date=May 14, 2014 }}. On 25 November 2018 [[2018 Kerch Strait incident|Russia blocked three Ukrainian Navy vessels from entering Sea of Azov]]{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-russia/russia-blocks-ukrainian-navy-from-entering-sea-of-azov-idUSKCN1NU0DL|title=Russia seizes Ukrainian ships near annexed Crimea after firing on them|first=Andrew|last=Osborn|publisher=|accessdate=26 November 2018}}. |- | [[Crimea]] | In 2014, Russian forces [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|occupied and annexed]] the [[Crimean peninsula]], seizing it from [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] territories. Russian claims to Crimea are not internationally recognized.Maria Raquel Freire, "Ukraine and the Restructuring of East-West Relations" in ''The Russian Challenge to the European Security Environment'' (ed. Roger E. Kanet), p. 201. The United Nations, through [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262|General Assembly Resolution 68/262]], affirmed that Crimea was part of Ukraine and that Russia's annexation is invalid.[https://news.un.org/en/story/2014/03/464812-backing-ukraines-territorial-integrity-un-assembly-declares-crimea-referendum Backing Ukraine’s territorial integrity, UN Assembly declares Crimea referendum invalid], United Nations News, March 27, 2014. Several nations imposed [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|international sanctions on Russia]] in reaction to its action. |- | [[Aegean dispute]], [[Imia/Kardak]] | {{GRC}}

| It is unclear whether the ROC actually claims Hong Kong.
